newsitem.title: INDIA: Cotton - Indian prices are seen subdued.
newsitem.headline: Cotton - Indian prices are seen subdued.

text.p: Widespread monsoon rains and the availability of stocks with state agencies will put cotton prices under pressure in coming days, traders said on Thursday.
They said the arrival of the four-month June-September monsoon after a marginal delay had covered the cotton tracts across the country.
Nearly 70 percent of India's 9.0 million hectares of area under cotton depends on these annual rains for its growth.
"The rainfall is normal. We expect the area under cotton to remain the same," said a leading cotton trader. "As of now, weather conditions are conducive to cotton crop."
A national conference of cotton traders had recently estimated the 1996/97 (October/September) crop at a record 16.78 million bales (one bale is 170 kg), up from 16.27 million in the previous season.
Traders said more than 95 percent of the current season's crop had already been marketed, with substantial quantities procured by state agencies.
"There's enough cotton available in the market," said another trader, adding that state agencies would start selling stocks over the next three months before the new crop came to market in October.
Cotton prices suffered a setback in the week to Thursday after firming initially, traders said.
Fresh buying by spinning mills exporting cotton yarn pushed prices up but the widespread monsoons in cotton tracts had pulled prices down, they said.

In spot, Bengal-deshi lost 10/20 rupees to 1,020/1,050 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) and Punjab saw-ginned 20 rupees to 1,825/1,880 rupees per maund. Punjab F-414 shed 10 rupees to 2,050/2,080 rupees per maund.
Timely and widespread rains had triggered selling by traders, said Mahesh Thakkar, a cotton trader.
Gujarat Kalyan fell 100/300 rupees to 13,900/14,200 rupees per candy (355.56 kg) and Wagad cotton lost 300 rupees to 12,600/12,700 rupees per candy.
Thakkar said the market's anticipation of further cotton exports did not materialise.
He said the state-owned agencies which bought cotton from farmers were holding huge stocks and were demanding more cotton for export.
"These agencies may sell their stocks in the domestic market in the coming days, which could result in a further fall in cotton prices," Thakkar said.
